clinical_study.brief_title: Intervention to Promote Water Consumption in School Lunchrooms
clinical_study.official_title: Grab a Cup, Fill it up! An Intervention to Promote Convenience of Drinking Water and Increase Student Water Consumption During School Lunch.

brief_summary.textblock: This study, randomized, delivered, and analyzed at the school level, evaluated the effect of simple, structural changes to school lunch rooms to make drinking water easier for students during lunch time. Half of the schools received posters promoting drinking water and installed cup dispensers stocked with cups next to lunchroom water fountains, while the other half received no intervention. The intervention outcomes were average water consumption and the proportion of students in the lunchroom who opted to drink water, as well as the proportion of students with sugary drinks at lunch. No identifying information on individual children was collected.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in average student water consumption at lunch

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in proportion of students drinking water at lunch
Change in proportion of students with sugar-sweetened beverages at lunch

intervention.intervention_name: Grab a Cup, Fill it Up
intervention.description: The intervention involved installing promotional posters encouraging students to drink water as well as cup dispensers stocked with disposable 5 ounce cups near water fountains in school lunchrooms.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: School in Boston Public School district in Boston, MA; had to have plumbed drinking water access in school cafeteria -
Exclusion Criteria: School had no plumbed drinking water access in cafeteria.
